project_metadata.paper_title: Barbarophonos: Language and Panhellenism in the Iliad
project_metadata.research_context: Philological analysis of linguistic representation in Homer's Iliad to examine the extent and nature of proto-Panhellenism in early Archaic Greece (eighth century BCE). Argues that differential treatment of language among Achaeans versus Trojan allies reveals a nascent, non-oppositional Panhellenic identity based on linguistic unity rather than Greek-Barbarian dichotomy.

evidence.description: Iliad 2.802-6: Iris warns Hektor about linguistic diversity among Trojan allies
evidence.verbatim_quote: Hektor, you especially I implore, act in this manner: There are many epikouroi in the great citadel of Priam, But there are different tongues among the wide-strewn human race; So let each man give word to those whom he rules, Let each, arranging the men of his polis for battle, be their leader.
evidence.notes: Author's translation. Greek text provided: alle d' allon glossa poluspereion anthropon indicates epikouroi speak mutually unintelligible languages requiring interpreters.

evidence.description: Iliad 2.867-69: Karians described as barbarophonos in Trojan Catalogue
evidence.verbatim_quote: But Nastes led the barbarophonoi Karians who held Miletos and the densely wooded mountain of Phthirai, and the streams of Maiandros, and the towering summits of Mukale.
evidence.notes: Only use of barbaros cognate or compound in the Iliad. Marks Karians as remote and strange.

evidence.description: Iliad 4.433-38: Trojan battle cry described as cacophonous due to mixed languages
evidence.verbatim_quote: But the Trojans, just as myriads of ewes stand in the sheep-pen of a rich man, waiting to be relieved of their white milk, bleat incessantly as they hear the voice of their lambs, the cry of the Trojans rose above the broad array; for there was no speech shared by them all, nor one voice, instead their tongue was mingled, as they were men summoned from many lands.
evidence.notes: Three words for language (throos, gerus, glossa) emphasise discord. Languages are diverse, numerous, and mutually unintelligible.

evidence.description: Odyssey 19.172-77: Odysseus describes linguistic diversity on Krete
evidence.verbatim_quote: Krete is a land, in the midst of the wine-dark sea, Lovely and rich, surrounded by water, and in it are many people, Countless people, and ninety poleis. And different tongues are mingled there; in it are Akhaioi, In it are great-hearted Eteokretes, in it are Kudones, And Dories with waving plumes, and divine Pelasgoi.
evidence.notes: Uses same verb (mignumi) as Il. 4.438. Same phrase alle d' allon glossa as Il. 2.804. Only recognition of linguistic diversity within Akhaian lands.

evidence.description: Hesiod Theogony 824-35: Typhoeus produces divine and animal sounds but no human speech
evidence.verbatim_quote: and there was speech in all his awful heads, making every sort of ungodly noise; and sometimes he uttered a sound as if for the gods' understanding; and at another time like a loud-bellowing bull, irrepressible of strength and proud of voice; and at another time like a lion, with merciless heart, and at another time mimicking a pack of whelps, shocking to hear, and at another time he hissed, and the great mountains rang out below.
evidence.notes: Typhoeus produces divine speech and animal sounds but no human speech. Contrasts divine-human linguistic distinction.

evidence.description: Iliad 1.403-4: Divine vs human names for Briareos/Aigaion
evidence.verbatim_quote: That creature the gods call Briareos, but all men Call the son of Aigaion, for in strength he is much greater than his father.
evidence.notes: Example of divine vs human naming convention in epic tradition.

evidence.description: Homeric Hymn to Delian Apollo 156-64: Delian maidens sing in all human languages
evidence.verbatim_quote: And this is a great wonder, its fame will never fade, The Delian maidens, attendants of the Far-Darter: When they hymn first to Apollo, Then to Leto and to Artemis the arrow-pourer, Remembering the men and women of old They sing a hymn, they enchant the tribes of people. They know how to mimic the speech and stammer of all people And each one would swear that he uttered the sounds himself, Thus their lovely song was joined.
evidence.notes: Each listener hears in own language. Presupposes human linguistic diversity. Whether skill or miracle, remarkable because of assumed language differences.

evidence.description: Homeric Hymn to Aphrodite 111-16: Aphrodite explains how she speaks Trojan language
evidence.verbatim_quote: And Otreus is my renowned father, perhaps you have heard of him somewhere, He who rules all of well-fortified Phrygia. And I know your tongue every bit as well as I know my own. For a Trojan nurse brought me up in our great hall: and she Reared me throughout the time I was a small child, when I was handed over to her from my own dear mother. This, indeed, is why I know your tongue so very well.
evidence.notes: Aphrodite disguised as Phrygian must explain linguistic competence. Mirrors Trojan-epikouroi language barriers in Iliad.

evidence.description: Oral tradition theory framework: Nagy on Iliad stabilisation and Vansina/Morris on institutional memory
evidence.verbatim_quote: by about 700 b.c.e. the poems were so widely diffused that opportunities for recomposition would have been limited by the expectations of a large, diverse, and informed audience... so long as it is evolving through recomposition, oral tradition only tends to retain information about institutions and relationships so long as they are immediately relevant to the poet's audience or relate directly to contemporary social structures.
evidence.notes: Combined evidence for oral tradition dating methodology. Theoretical framework for dating abstract concepts like linguistic arrangements to moment of stabilisation.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both evidence items support the same dating methodology claims (C001, C014, C015). Cited together by author to establish theoretical framework.

evidence.description: Cartledge on absence of oppositional identity in Archaic period
evidence.verbatim_quote: Cartledge, for example, contrasts the Archaic Period, where there is no such oppositional identity, with the Classical Era, when 'Greeks . . . construct their identities negatively, by means of a series of polarized oppositions of themselves to what they were not'
evidence.notes: Scholarly consensus that Greek-barbarian dichotomy arose during/after Persian Wars.

evidence.description: Snodgrass, Nagy, and Hall on eighth/sixth-century Panhellenism indicators
evidence.verbatim_quote: Both recognize, for example, the Olympic Games, the Delphic Oracle, and the Homeric epics themselves as indicators of eighth-century Panhellenism... According to J. Hall, the sixth century b.c.e. constitutes a critical juncture in the slow evolution of aggregative proto-Panhellenism, marked especially by the founding of the Hellenion at Naukratis
evidence.notes: Alternative scholarly view supporting nascent Panhellenism built from local identities.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items provide scholarly evidence for alternative dating of proto-Panhellenism emergence. Support same claim about aggregative identity formation.

evidence.description: Herodotus on language as element of Hellenic identity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion.
evidence.notes: Classical evidence for language's centrality to Panhellenism.

evidence.description: Cartledge on absence of 'barbarian' term in Homer
evidence.verbatim_quote: Cartledge (1993, 13) observes that 'Not once is "barbarian" used as either a substantive or adjective in all . . . of Homer.'
evidence.notes: Supports claim that barbarophonos is only barbaros-cognate in Iliad.

evidence.description: Mackie on Akhaian order vs Trojan disorder through language
evidence.verbatim_quote: When the Trojans march out at the beginning of Book 3, they are still dominated by undifferentiated clamor (klaggê). With their mixed languages, the Trojans cannot function as an articulate group... Because Greek is their common language, the units of the Achaean army form an organic whole, a kosmos 'ordering' of tribes and phratries.
evidence.notes: Mackie's analysis of linguistic unity as marker of Akhaian cohesion. Contrast between Akhaian linguistic homogeneity and Trojan heterogeneity.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both evidence items from Mackie 1996 support the same claims about Akhaian-Trojan linguistic contrast. Cited in same analytical context.

evidence.description: Simpson and Lazenby on geographical arrangement of Trojan Catalogue
evidence.verbatim_quote: The contingents seem to be grouped together in five geographical areas—the Troad, the European allies from beyond the Hellespont, the Far Eastern allies (Paphlagonians and Alizonians), the Near Eastern allies (Mysians and Phrygians), and the allies from south of the Troad—and in the last four cases, the list appears to begin with the contingent from nearest Troy, and to end with the one from farthest away.
evidence.notes: Karians placed next-to-last in geographically ordered catalogue, reinforcing their remoteness.

evidence.description: Iliad 3.181-90: Priam mentions Otreus as contemporary of his youth
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the same passage, which occurs as Priam praises the number of men under Agamemnon's command, Priam favorably compares the Akhaian host to the largest army he has previously seen, the Phrygians under Otreus and Mygdon who arrayed themselves against the Amazons.
evidence.notes: Links Hymn to Aphrodite's Otreus to Trojan cycle, supporting linguistic barrier between Phrygians and Trojans.

evidence.description: Language mentioned only once in Catalogues of Iliad 2
evidence.verbatim_quote: Notably, language is only mentioned once in the Catalogues of Iliad 2, in which Homer delineates and describes the opposing forces. Even here it is of relatively minor importance, marked by a single adjective, before the poet returns to more commonly invoked and salient criteria of identity
evidence.notes: Observational evidence about relative importance of language vs place of origin in identity markers.

evidence.description: No language barrier between Akhaians and Trojans; Akhaian linguistic uniformity
evidence.verbatim_quote: never in the Iliad is there a language barrier between Akhaian and Trojan; heroes from both camps freely communicate in face-to-face encounters... While linguistic diversity is emphasized among the epikouroi defending Troy, it is entirely absent from the Akhaian force besieging the city.
evidence.notes: Critical observation distinguishing Iliad from later Greek-barbarian dichotomy. Key differential pattern supporting proto-Panhellenism thesis.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both observational items from author's analysis appear in same concluding section and support the same pattern of claims about Akhaian-Trojan linguistic dynamics.

evidence.description: Hymn to Demeter shows no linguistic barrier with Kretan disguise
evidence.verbatim_quote: When Demeter disguises herself as an old woman from Krete and seeks refuge in Eleusis, she has no difficulty talking with the daughters of King Keleos
evidence.notes: Contrastive evidence: linguistic barriers don't always arise when gods assume mortal personas.

evidence.description: Nagy on fusion of Delian and Pythian traditions
evidence.verbatim_quote: In his analysis of the Homeric Hymn to Apollo, Nagy believes that the fusion of the Delian and Pythian traditions in this hymn reflects the unification of not just artistic, but also socio-religious traditions—bringing together not only divergent stories, but also diverse audiences.
evidence.notes: Evidence for intercultural synthesis contributing to Panhellenism.

evidence.description: Finley on common names as symbol of Greek unity
evidence.verbatim_quote: He sees Homer's use of (multiple) common names for the Akhaians as a metaphor for early Panhellenism: 'The presence of a common name (or names) is a symbol that Greek history proper had been launched.'
evidence.notes: Multiple names (Akhaians, Danaans, Argives) as symbol of unity-in-diversity.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad reveals a nascent, non-oppositional proto-Panhellenism based on linguistic unity, distinct from the later Greek-Barbarian dichotomy that emerged after the Persian Wars.
claims.verbatim_quote: Even though no language barrier separates Akhaians from Trojans in the epics, the selective recognition of linguistic diversity among Trojan epikouroi, versus the homogeneity of the Akhaians, offers a glimpse of an undeveloped and unstable proto-Panhellenism.

claims.claim_text: The epikouroi (allies) of the Trojans speak various mutually unintelligible languages, requiring interpreters to communicate.
claims.verbatim_quote: The phrase alle d' allon glossa poluspereion anthropon ('but there are different tongues among the wide-strewn human race') makes it clear that the epikouroi speak various mutually unintelligible languages; otherwise, there would be no need to dispatch each leader to command his own troops.

claims.claim_text: In the Iliad, linguistic variation among epikouroi follows the contours of polis and military contingent rather than defining ethnic or socio-linguistic groups.
claims.verbatim_quote: In this case, language does not define particular ethnic or socio-linguistic groups. Instead, linguistic variation among the epikouroi follows the contours of other aspects of identity more frequently invoked by Homer (and found among both Trojan and Akhaian forces): polis and military contingent... It is assumed that all members of a single polis community (and consequently the military contingent based upon it) speak the same language, but that language barriers may arise between poleis.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims addressed same relationship between polis/military identity and language. Merged to create single coherent interpretive claim.

claims.claim_text: In Iliad 2.802-6, each military leader must interpret for his own troops due to the linguistic diversity among Trojan allies.
claims.verbatim_quote: So let each man give word to those whom he rules, Let each, arranging the men of his polis for battle, be their leader.

claims.claim_text: Barbarophonos denotes strange speech generally rather than merely non-Akhaian speech; the Karians' placement next-to-last in the geographically-ordered Trojan Catalogue reinforces their remoteness.
claims.verbatim_quote: It is likely that the adjective barbarophonos here does not denote merely non-Greek (or, more properly, non-Akhaian) speech, but instead carries the force of strange speech more generally... The idea of remoteness is reinforced by the fact that the Karians occur next-to-last in the Trojan Catalogue, which appears to be arranged in geographical order.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims concerned interpretation of barbarophonos and Karian remoteness in the Catalogue. Combined for coherent analysis.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad contains only one use of a barbaros cognate or compound (barbarophonos), which lacks the negative connotations of the later Classical term 'barbarian'.
claims.verbatim_quote: This passage marks the only use of a barbaros cognate or compound in the Iliad.

claims.claim_text: The cacophony of the Trojan host's battle cry results from their linguistic diversity, emphasising that languages spoken among the epikouroi are diverse, numerous, and mutually unintelligible.
claims.verbatim_quote: Three words, throos, gerus, and glossa, used for language in two separate clauses, invoke the discord of the scene, emphasizing the fact that the languages spoken among the epikouroi are diverse, numerous, and—when considered in the context of Iliad 2.802–6, where interpreters prove necessary— mutually unintelligible.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic variation in the Trojan host depends upon place of origin, with language following the contours of geographic identity.
claims.verbatim_quote: just as language is subordinate to polis and military divisions in Iliad 2.802–6, linguistic variation here depends upon place of origin: glossa memikto ('their tongue was mingled') because they were polykleitoi ('summoned from many lands').

claims.claim_text: The Odyssey passage on Krete (19.172-77) represents the only recognition of linguistic diversity within Akhaian lands in early literature, using the same vocabulary as the Iliad to evoke strangeness and distance.
claims.verbatim_quote: The only recognition of linguistic diversity within Akhaian lands found in early literature occurs in the Odyssey... Although the linkage between ethnicity and language in Odyssey 19.175–77 distinguishes it from the three analogous passages in the Iliad, the vocabulary and wording are very similar to Iliad 2.804 and 4.438, while the intention of the passage, evoking as it does strangeness and distance, mirrors that of the Karian entry in the Trojan Catalogue.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims analysed the same Odyssey Krete passage. Combined into single comparative claim.

claims.claim_text: Epic poetry uses language to explore the division between human and divine, with gods having their own speech distinct from human speech; Hesiod never recognises differences between human languages.
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike Homer, Hesiod never recognizes differences between human languages. Instead, his only mention of language involves divine speech, contrasted with the inarticulate sounds made by animals... The gods are clearly thought of as having their own speech, as different from human speech as the roaring of a lion or the hissing of a snake.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims addressed divine-human linguistic distinction in Hesiod and epic tradition. Combined for thematic coherence.

claims.claim_text: The Hymn to Delian Apollo presupposes human linguistic diversity, making the maidens' universal intelligibility remarkable - the only instance in early epic where human linguistic diversity is recognised generically outside the Trojan War context.
claims.verbatim_quote: for the scene to be considered remarkable requires the imagined audience to come to the performance of the maidens speaking a multitude of languages... Perhaps more importantly, it also provides the only instance in early epic poetry where human linguistic diversity is recognized in a generic way, outside the context of the Trojan epikouroi and the Trojan War.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims analysed the same Hymn to Delian Apollo passage. Combined for single coherent interpretation.

claims.claim_text: In the Hymn to Aphrodite, linguistic barriers arise between Trojans and Phrygians, mirroring the Trojan-epikouroi pattern from the Iliad.
claims.verbatim_quote: Just as interpreters were employed in the Iliad to facilitate communication between Trojans and epikouroi, here Aphrodite concocts an identity as a Phrygian princess who can only speak with Ankhises because she was brought up by a Trojan nurse, who taught her Ankhises' language.

claims.claim_text: The image of linguistic diversity among Trojan epikouroi found in the Iliad had solidified within the epic tradition, as shown by the Hymn to Aphrodite's need to explain Phrygian-Trojan communication.
claims.verbatim_quote: In this context, the poet's need to provide a Phrygian princess with a Trojan education in order to explain how she can converse with Ankhises illustrates the degree to which the image of linguistic diversity among the epikouroi of the Trojans found in the Iliad had solidified within the epic tradition.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad substantially preserves versions current during the late eighth century BCE, with stabilisation around 700 BCE.
claims.verbatim_quote: I believe, however, that the poems as we have them substantially preserve versions current during the late eighth century, with the Iliad perhaps somewhat earlier than the Odyssey.

claims.claim_text: Abstractions like linguistic arrangements evolve rapidly through oral recomposition until epics become fixed, reflecting conditions contemporary with stabilisation rather than Bronze Age realities.
claims.verbatim_quote: Precise linguistic arrangements (and the epics are very consistent in this regard) represent just such an abstraction, evolving rapidly through recomposition until the epics became relatively fixed due to wide dispersion and concomitant audience expectations... Physical things, be they objects or places, are much more durable in oral tradition... By contrast, so long as it is evolving through recomposition, oral tradition only tends to retain information about institutions and relationships so long as they are immediately relevant.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims elaborated oral tradition theory for dating linguistic content. Combined into single theoretical claim.

claims.claim_text: The consensus holds that the Greek-barbarian dichotomy arose during and after the Persian Wars; scholars who see Panhellenism as emerging primarily through opposition to a 'barbarian Other' tend to downplay pre-war Panhellenism.
claims.verbatim_quote: The consensus holds that the dichotomy between Greek and barbarian arose during and after the Persian Wars and that any Panhellenic identity based upon it, therefore, does not precede the advent of the Classical Era... Scholars who see Panhellenism as emerging primarily through opposition to a barbarian 'Other' tend to downplay the extent of Panhellenism before the Persian Wars.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims described related aspects of scholarly consensus on Greek-barbarian dichotomy timing.

claims.claim_text: Those who view Panhellenism as aggregated from disparate local identities allow for its earlier appearance, at least in nascent form, with eighth or sixth-century BCE indicators.
claims.verbatim_quote: Those who view Panhellenism as aggregated from disparate local and regional identities allow for its earlier appearance, at least in a limited or nascent form.

claims.claim_text: In the Classical Era, language was central to Panhellenism, with speaking a single tongue as one of three central elements of Hellenic identity.
claims.verbatim_quote: In the Classical Era, language was central to Panhellenism. Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion.

claims.claim_text: The contrast between Trojan cacophony and Akhaian linguistic unity represents a broader contrast between Trojan disorder and Akhaian order/cohesion.
claims.verbatim_quote: In this context, the Akhaian unity of language, versus the Trojan-allied disunity, is a contrast between Trojan clamor and chaos on the one hand and Akhaian cohesion and order on the other.

claims.claim_text: Through poetic emphasis or suppression, linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan epikouroi while entirely absent from the Akhaian forces.
claims.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, through poetic emphasis or suppression, linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan epikouroi (allies or companions) defending the city, while it is absent from the Akhaian forces besieging Troy.

claims.claim_text: Language is not the most important criterion of identity in the Iliad; it is coupled with or subordinate to place of origin or membership in military retinue.
claims.verbatim_quote: First, language is not the most important criterion of identity; in all three passages it is coupled with, or even subordinate to, place of origin or membership in a particular military retinue.

claims.claim_text: No hard linguistic dividing line exists between Akhaians and Trojans; Akhaian and Trojan heroes communicate freely in face-to-face encounters.
claims.verbatim_quote: On the one hand, Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely with one another; no hard linguistic dividing line between Akhaians and others emerges over the course of the epic, nor does it appear that the later, categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy has yet emerged.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad lacks a clearly oppositional Panhellenic identity but contains a nascent identity based on linguistic unity - recognition of Akhaian homogeneity against the linguistic diversity of Trojan epikouroi.
claims.verbatim_quote: In other words, although the Iliad lacks a clearly oppositional Panhellenic identity with consistent differentiation between 'Akhaian-speakers' and others, it contains a nascent Panhellenic identity based on linguistic unity, a recognition of Akhaian homogeneity of language against the linguistic diversity of the Trojan epikouroi.

claims.claim_text: The development of Panhellenism is captured at the stage of an operationally unified 'us' versus a diverse, plural 'those others' - not yet a unified us vs unified them.
claims.verbatim_quote: Instead, the development of Panhellenism has been captured at the stage of an operationally but incompletely unified 'us' versus a diverse, plural 'those others.' The Greeks of the late eighth century b.c.e. shared enough to accept a common epic tradition, in which they recognized the Akhaians as an idealized vision of themselves: ordered and unified; close, native, and familiar.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic barriers do not always arise when gods assume mortal personas in the Homeric Hymns, as shown by the Hymn to Demeter, but the Aphrodite case specifically involves communication between Phrygian and Trojan.
claims.verbatim_quote: Linguistic barriers do not always arise when a god takes on the persona of a foreign mortal in the Homeric Hymns. When Demeter disguises herself as an old woman from Krete and seeks refuge in Eleusis, she has no difficulty talking with the daughters of King Keleos

claims.claim_text: The broad acceptance of the Homeric epics among Greeks indicates an 'intercultural synthesis' contributing to nascent Panhellenism.
claims.verbatim_quote: More generally, just as Nagy argues that proliferation of the Homeric epics by the late eighth century b.c.e. indicates an approximate date for the stabilization of the oral tradition, he also cites the broad acceptance of the epics among the Greeks as evidence—along with the rise of institutions such as the Olympic Games and Delphic Oracle—for an emerging 'intercultural synthesis' that contributed to a nascent sense of Panhellenism.

claims.claim_text: The multiplicity of common names for Homer's Greeks (Akhaians, Danaans, Argives) reflects tension between unity and diversity, with the presence of common names symbolising early Panhellenism.
claims.verbatim_quote: Just as the existence of a multiplicity of common names for Homer's 'Greeks'—Akhaians, Danaans, Argives—sheds light on the tension between unity and diversity among the Akhaians, the linguistic landscape of the Iliad provides a window into the complex nature of identity in the epics

claims.claim_text: The Trojans are not represented as an undifferentiated barbarian horde; linguistic diversity among epikouroi is neither ignored nor suppressed, and every reference to variation in language occurs within the Trojan sphere.
claims.verbatim_quote: Nor are the Trojans represented merely as some undifferentiated barbarian horde. Indeed, linguistic diversity among the Trojan epikouroi is neither ignored nor suppressed, and every reference to variation in language occurs within the Trojan sphere.

claims.claim_text: Assigning later Greek-Barbarian dichotomy understanding to eighth-century BCE performance is anachronistic and unsupported by the linguistic situation in the epics.
claims.verbatim_quote: Even though later Greeks—after the Persian Wars, perhaps—may have directly equated Akhaians with Greeks and Trojans with barbarians as they heard or read the Iliad, assigning such an understanding of identity to an eighth-century b.c.e. performance is anachronistic, unsupported by the linguistic situation depicted in the epics.

claims.claim_text: In early epic poetry, strange language serves as a marker of alterity - joining Odysseus' exotic Krete, Typhoeus, and the remote Karians as indicators of strangeness, difference, and distance.
claims.verbatim_quote: In short, although the speaking of different languages occurs only occasionally in the early epic tradition, when it does it tends to serve one of several specific ends. In the Odyssey and in the Theogony, and sometimes in the Iliad, the speaking of a strange language indicates just that, strangeness, difference, and distance.

claims.claim_text: Human linguistic variation accounts for more instances of linguistic diversity in early epic than the human-divine dichotomy, even among examples from outside the Iliad.
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, human linguistic variation accounts for more of the instances of linguistic diversity noted in the early epic tradition than does the human-divine dichotomy, even among examples taken from outside the Iliad.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: Oral tradition theory provides a valid methodological framework for dating abstract concepts in Homeric epics to the period of their stabilisation.
trigger_text: I believe, however, that the poems as we have them substantially preserve versions current during the late eighth century
especially for the reason Gregory Nagy proposed: that by about 700 b.c.e. the poems were so widely diffused that opportunities for recomposition would have been limited
Due to the nature of oral tradition, the poem for the most part reflects beliefs about language and identity roughly contemporary with the moment of stabilization
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The entire argument depends on accepting Nagy's oral tradition theory and the premise that abstract concepts (like linguistic arrangements) are contemporaneous with stabilisation. This theoretical framework is assumed rather than demonstrated within the paper itself.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: The pattern of linguistic representation in the Iliad is deliberate poetic choice rather than accidental or inherited from earlier tradition.
trigger_text: through poetic emphasis or suppression, linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan epikouroi

These artistic devices work because during the late eighth century, around the time the Iliad stabilized in its final form, both resonated with—and perhaps even contributed to—an emerging sense of Panhellenism
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument assumes intentional poetic selection in depicting linguistic diversity only among Trojans while suppressing it among Akhaians. The alternative - that this pattern is accidental or inherited from older tradition - is not systematically addressed.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: The linguistic situation depicted in the Iliad can be taken as evidence for historical Greek attitudes about identity, not merely as literary convention.
trigger_text: the linguistic landscape of the Iliad provides a window into the complex nature of identity in the epics, and among the Greeks of the late eighth century b.c.e.

the unity of the Akhaians in the Iliad would have been more effective as a literary device if it resonated with a genuine sense of Panhellenism emerging among poet and audience in the eighth century b.c.e.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper moves from textual analysis to historical claims about Greek identity. This requires assuming that epic conventions reflect actual attitudes rather than being purely literary artifice. Mackie is cited as cautioning against this move, but the author proceeds anyway.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: Three Iliad passages constitute a sufficient sample to establish a 'consistent pattern' of linguistic representation.
trigger_text: Three passages in the Iliad directly address the speaking of different languages (Il. 2.802–6, 2.867, 4.433–38)
In all three, Homer recognizes strangeness or diversity of speech among the epikouroi of the Trojans
the instances of linguistic diversity that do occur in the Iliad follow a consistent pattern
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument relies on three passages to establish a 'consistent pattern'. The disciplinary assumption is that this limited sample is representative and not selective - that there are no counter-examples or that such passages would survive oral transmission.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: If the Iliad were composed/stabilised significantly later than 700 BCE, the linguistic patterns would reflect the post-Persian Wars Greek-Barbarian dichotomy rather than the nascent proto-Panhellenism observed.
trigger_text: Even though later Greeks—after the Persian Wars, perhaps—may have directly equated Akhaians with Greeks and Trojans with barbarians
assigning such an understanding of identity to an eighth-century b.c.e. performance is anachronistic, unsupported by the linguistic situation depicted in the epics
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument implicitly relies on the contrapositive: if the Iliad showed clear Greek-Barbarian dichotomy, it would suggest later composition/revision. The absence of such dichotomy supports early dating. This creates a somewhat circular relationship between dating and interpretation.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: The Greek terms for language (glossa, throos, gerus) and related vocabulary carried similar semantic ranges and connotations in the eighth century BCE as they did in later Greek.
trigger_text: Three words, throos, gerus, and glossa, used for language in two separate clauses, invoke the discord of the scene

The phrase alle d' allon glossa poluspereion anthropon ('but there are different tongues among the wide-strewn human race') makes it clear that the epikouroi speak various mutually unintelligible languages
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The philological argument depends on interpreting Homeric Greek vocabulary through later Classical meanings. The semantic development of these terms between the eighth century and Classical period is assumed to be stable enough for this interpretation.

implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: Silence about Akhaian linguistic diversity constitutes positive evidence for perceived Akhaian linguistic unity, not merely poetic indifference to the topic.
trigger_text: linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan epikouroi (allies or companions) defending the city, while it is absent from the Akhaian forces besieging Troy
This differential treatment of Akhaian and Trojan forces reveals a notion of 'pan-Akhaian' linguistic uniformity
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument from silence assumes that absence of evidence for Akhaian linguistic diversity equals evidence of perceived uniformity. Alternative explanations (irrelevance to plot, poetic convention, narrative focus) are not systematically excluded.

research_designs.name: Oral tradition dating methodology (Nagy framework)
